history.content: It's an interesting mix of classes you have there. CS 152 and CS 168 are pretty useful for the industry provided that's the industry you want to go in. CS 168 is more general purpose while CS 152 is more niche in my opinion. If you want to get more into computer architecture, take CS152. EE 120 is of absolute no use (my hyperbole just to highlight a perspective) if you do not plan on taking more signal classes ( EE123, EE128 and so on). That being said, if you want to learn more about signal processing and stuff, it's very important you take it early and learn your fundamentals well. I took EECS 149 embedded system class last semester and I was very very disappointed. In my personal opinion, you are better off taking CS 162 operating system which covers similar grounds as EECS 149 but more in depth and more useful (and harder and more work of course!).

children.subject: Not to say useless but you will be familiar with a lot of stuff in EECS 149 with some background in CS 162. So I do not recommend taking it in your case. However, I'm speaking from my own experience so as the instructor changes for next semester, the material may evolve as well but I do not expect a huge shift though.

Ah ok, thanks for the feedback. I am in CS 162 right now, and I'm enjoying it (although it is fairly challenging). I do have plans to take classes such as EE 121 and EE 123. Just to be clear, EECS 149 is useless if I already have knowledge of CS 162?

history.content:
I'm planning on taking at max three of these four classes next semester, along with a fairly light humanities course. Which combination would be the most useful for the industry / most manageable?

Thanks!
history.subject: EECS 149 + CS 152 + CS 168 + EE 120
